Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Experimental Investigation of the Flow Fields over Bio-Inspired and Finite Span Wings Undergoing Dynamic Stall

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0845882
Bohl

Airfoils are central components of many important technologies, including wind turbines, turbomachinery and aircraft, and better understanding of flows over airfoils is critical to their continued development. When an airfoil is placed at a sufficiently high angle of attack, the flow over the surface can separate causing loss of lift or stall. Stall is usually detrimental to performance. Historically, the study of airfoil dynamics has centered on airfoils placed at fixed angles of attack. This view is insufficient to describe the physics of airfoils in motion, where the developed lift and the stall angle are considerably higher. Under these conditions the loss of lift can be abrupt causing rapid changes in the aerodynamic and loading characteristics. This phenomenon is known as dynamic stall (DS). This experimental study will develop a bio-inspired strategy to control or delay DS and quantify the velocity and vorticity fields in the critical region near the airfoil leading edge for finite aspect ratio airfoils.

Dynamic stall plays a key role in the development of two transformational technologies: wind power generation and the development of high-performance aircraft. It is widely anticipated that the Joint Strike Fighter will be the last manned fighter developed for the US Department of Defense. Removing the pilot increases the performance potential by increasing the allowable forces experienced during extreme maneuvers for which dynamic stall is central. Dynamic stall also results in high unsteady loads on wind turbine blades which, if controlled, can increase their performance and durability. The lack of experimental data for finite span wings undergoing DS hinders the development of predictive models and represents.

The PI's educational objectives include the development of new curricula for college and high school courses. Graduate students will gain experience by acting as mentors to the undergraduates who will enhance their educational experience through focused research. Students will be recruited from primarily under-represented groups using Clarkson University's pipeline programs such as the NSF sponsored S-STEM program. A senior-level problem-based undergraduate course in bio-fluid mechanics will be developed addressing the concept of biomimicry using the PI's research as a case example. A similar collaborative effort will be undertaken with a local high school. Once developed, these materials will be disseminated to other area teachers through the Clarkson University Office of Educational Partnerships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Dynamic stall on “infinite”, “finite” and "bio-inspired" wings has been studied experimentally using Molecular Tagging Velocimetry (MTV) to understanding the complex, unsteady, flow dynamics that can affect helicopters, highly maneuverable aircraft, wind turbines, and insects. The velocity and vorticity fields around the suction sides of the airfoils have been quantified and compared for constant pitch rate motions. The "infinite span" wing is a classic unsteady aerodynamic problem that provides the baseline comparison, while the "finite span" and "bio-inspired" wings provide new results. Finite span wings have been less studied than infinite wings; however, they are of technological importance as all real wings have effects due to the presence of the wing tips. These data quantify the “Omega” vortex structure previously only observed in flow visualization and surface pressure measurements. The results show that the finite span wing differs from the baseline case at all locations along the span in several key metrics (circulation and separation time). The circulation and separation time determine the angle to which an airfoil can be pitched before the sudden loss in lift occurs. The velocity and vorticity data confirm that stall is delayed for finite span wings. Finally, the results of the study for the finite span wing provide needed well resolved experimental data sets for computational comparison.

The bio-inspired wing was created based on the protuberances or bumps found on the leading edge of the humpback whale flipper. Previous studies of humpback whale inspired wings have focused on the static aerodynamics of this wing. Observation of swimming humpback whales shows the flipper is rarely held in a fixed orientation. The current study was the first time that this geometry was investigated for dynamic stall conditions. The working hypothesis of the study was that the leading edge protuberances are passive means for controlling dynamic stall. This enables the flipper to be rapidly “actuated” to higher angles of attack by delaying dynamic stall. The results show that the leading edge protuberances clearly delay the onset of dynamic stall to higher angles. Additionally, the dynamic stall vortex is stronger and remains closer to the wing surface than the baseline case. This indicates that the bio-inspired wing should develop more lift, and hold the lift to higher angles than conventional wings confirming the working hypothesis of the study.

 

Broader Impacts

This study has supported the education of 4 graduate students and 5 undergraduate students. The project has included three women researchers and several "first generation" college students. Two of the undergraduate students are continuing their graduate education. Along with traditional graduate study activities (course work, seminars, etc.), the graduate students involved in this project have been trained in the use of Laser Induced Fluorescence and Molecular Tagging Velocimetry, the diagnostics used during the experimental effort. The students (graduate and undergraduate) have presented their findings at local and national conferences and have been actively involved in writing results of their work for journal publication. The graduate students involved in this project have each been responsible for mentoring undergraduate researchers. Three invited talks on the work have been presented by the PI to date on the results of this study.

Two journal articles have been published to date from the work supported by this grant. A third article has submitted and is currently under review. Two additional journal articles are currently in-process dealing with the finite span and bio-inspired wing results. Two graduate thesis and one graduate project report have als...

Broader Impacts This study has supported the education of 4 graduate students and 5 undergraduate students. The project has included three women researchers and several "first generation" college students. Two of the undergraduate students are continuing their graduate education. Along with traditional graduate study activities (course work, seminars, etc.), the graduate students involved in this project have been trained in the use of Laser Induced Fluorescence and Molecular Tagging Velocimetry, the diagnostics used during the experimental effort. The students (graduate and undergraduate) have presented their findings at local and national conferences and have been actively involved in writing results of their work for journal publication. The graduate students involved in this project have each been responsible for mentoring undergraduate researchers. Three invited talks on the work have been presented by the PI to date on the results of this study. Two journal articles have been published to date from the work supported by this grant. A third article has submitted and is currently under review. Two additional journal articles are currently in-process dealing with the finite span and bio-inspired wing results. Two graduate thesis and one graduate project report have also been written from the work in this project.
